// CHANGE: Define core type-level operations for extracting OpenAPI types
// WHY: Enable compile-time type safety without runtime overhead through pure type transformations
// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "Success / HttpError —è–≤–ª—è—é—Ç—Å—è –∫–æ—Ä—Ä–µ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º–∏ —Å—É–º–º–∞–º–∏ (status ‚Üí —Ç–æ—á–Ω—ã–π —Ç–∏–ø body) —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ –∏–∑ OpenAPI —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤"
// REF: issue-2, section 3.1, 4.1-4.3
// SOURCE: n/a
// FORMAT THEOREM: ‚àÄ Op ‚àà Operations: ResponseVariant<Op> = Success<Op> ‚äé Failure<Op>
// PURITY: CORE
// INVARIANT: All types computed at compile time, no runtime operations
// COMPLEXITY: O(1) compile-time / O(0) runtime

import type { HttpMethod, PathsWithMethod } from "openapi-typescript-helpers"

/**
 * Extract all paths that support a given HTTP method
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Result ‚äÜ paths
 */
export type PathsForMethod<
  Paths extends object,
  Method extends HttpMethod
> = PathsWithMethod<Paths, Method>

/**
 * Extract operation definition for a path and method
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant ‚àÄ path ‚àà Paths, method ‚àà Methods: Operation<Paths, path, method> = Paths[path][method]
 */
export type OperationFor<
  Paths extends object,
  Path extends keyof Paths,
  Method extends HttpMethod
> = Method extends keyof Paths[Path] ? Paths[Path][Method] : never

/**
 * Extract all response definitions from an operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 */
export type ResponsesFor<Op> = Op extends { responses: infer R } ? R : never

// ============================================================================
// Request-side typing (path/method ‚Üí params/query/body)
// ============================================================================

/**
 * Extract path parameters from operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Returns path params type or undefined if none
 */
export type PathParamsFor<Op> = Op extends { parameters: { path: infer P } }
  ? P extends Record<string, infer V> ? Record<string, V>
  : never
  : undefined

/**
 * Extract query parameters from operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Returns query params type or undefined if none
 */
export type QueryParamsFor<Op> = Op extends { parameters: { query?: infer Q } } ? Q
  : undefined

/**
 * Extract request body type from operation
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Returns body type or undefined if no requestBody
 */
export type RequestBodyFor<Op> = Op extends { requestBody: { content: infer C } }
  ? C extends { "application/json": infer J } ? J
  : C extends { [key: string]: infer V } ? V
  : never
  : undefined

/**
 * Check if path params are required
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 */

export type HasRequiredPathParams<Op> = Op extends { parameters: { path: infer P } }
  ? P extends Record<PropertyKey, string | number | boolean> ? keyof P extends never ? false : true
  : false
  : false

/**
 * Check if request body is required
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 */
export type HasRequiredBody<Op> = Op extends { requestBody: infer RB } ? RB extends { content: object } ? true
  : false
  : false

/**
 * Build request options type from operation with all constraints
 * - params: required if path has required parameters
 * - query: optional, typed from operation
 * - body: required if operation has requestBody (accepts typed object OR string)
 *
 * For request body:
 * - Users can pass either the typed object (preferred, for type safety)
 * - Or a pre-stringified JSON string with headers (for backwards compatibility)
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Options type is fully derived from operation definition
 */
export type RequestOptionsFor<Op> =
  & (HasRequiredPathParams<Op> extends true ? { readonly params: PathParamsFor<Op> }
    : { readonly params?: PathParamsFor<Op> })
  & (HasRequiredBody<Op> extends true ? { readonly body: RequestBodyFor<Op> | BodyInit }
    : { readonly body?: RequestBodyFor<Op> | BodyInit })
  & { readonly query?: QueryParamsFor<Op> }
  & { readonly headers?: HeadersInit }
  & { readonly signal?: AbortSignal }

/**
 * Extract status codes from responses
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Result = { s | s ‚àà keys(Responses) }
 */
export type StatusCodes<Responses> = keyof Responses & (number | string)

/**
 * Extract content types for a specific status code
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 */
export type ContentTypesFor<
  Responses,
  Status extends StatusCodes<Responses>
> = Status extends keyof Responses ? Responses[Status] extends { content: infer C } ? keyof C & string
  : "none"
  : never

/**
 * Extract body type for a specific status and content-type
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Strict correlation: Body type depends on both status and content-type
 */
export type BodyFor<
  Responses,
  Status extends StatusCodes<Responses>,
  ContentType extends ContentTypesFor<Responses, Status>
> = Status extends keyof Responses
  ? Responses[Status] extends { content: infer C } ? ContentType extends keyof C ? C[ContentType]
    : never
  : ContentType extends "none" ? undefined
  : never
  : never

/**
 * Build a correlated success response variant (status + contentType + body)
 * Used for 2xx responses that go to the success channel.
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant ‚àÄ variant: variant.body = BodyFor<Responses, variant.status, variant.contentType>
 */
export type ResponseVariant<
  Responses,
  Status extends StatusCodes<Responses>,
  ContentType extends ContentTypesFor<Responses, Status>
> = {
  readonly status: Status
  readonly contentType: ContentType
  readonly body: BodyFor<Responses, Status, ContentType>
}

/**
 * Build a correlated HTTP error response variant (status + contentType + body + _tag)
 * Used for non-2xx responses (4xx, 5xx) that go to the error channel.
 *
 * The `_tag: "HttpError"` discriminator allows distinguishing HTTP errors from BoundaryErrors.
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant ‚àÄ variant: variant.body = BodyFor<Responses, variant.status, variant.contentType>
 */
export type HttpErrorResponseVariant<
  Responses,
  Status extends StatusCodes<Responses>,
  ContentType extends ContentTypesFor<Responses, Status>
> = {
  readonly _tag: "HttpError"
  readonly status: Status
  readonly contentType: ContentType
  readonly body: BodyFor<Responses, Status, ContentType>
}

/**
 * Build all response variants for given responses
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 */
type AllResponseVariants<Responses> = StatusCodes<Responses> extends infer Status
  ? Status extends StatusCodes<Responses>
    ? ContentTypesFor<Responses, Status> extends infer CT
      ? CT extends ContentTypesFor<Responses, Status> ? ResponseVariant<Responses, Status, CT>
      : never
    : never
  : never
  : never

/**
 * Generic 2xx status detection without hardcoding
 * Uses template literal type to check if status string starts with "2"
 *
 * Works with any 2xx status including non-standard ones like 250.
 *
 * @pure true - compile-time only
 * @invariant Is2xx<S> = true ‚ü∫ 200 ‚â§ S < 300
 */
export type Is2xx<S extends string | number> = `${S}` extends `2${string}` ? true : false

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`

- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript
// CHANGE: <–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∫–æ–µ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// WHY: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ/–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–µ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ>
// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "<–¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–∞—è —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–∞ —Ç—Ä–µ–±–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è>" | n/a
// REF: <REQ-ID –∏–∑ RTM –∏–ª–∏ –Ω–æ–º–µ—Ä —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// SOURCE: <—Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–∞ —Å –¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–æ–π –∏–∑ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–µ–≥–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞> | n/a
// FORMAT THEOREM: <‚àÄx ‚àà Domain: P(x) ‚Üí Q(f(x))>
// PURITY: CORE | SHELL - —è–≤–Ω–∞—è –º–∞—Ä–∫–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∫–∞ —Å–ª–æ—è
// EFFECT: Effect<Success, Error, Requirements> - –¥–ª—è shell —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π
// INVARIANT: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–π –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏>
// COMPLEXITY: O(time)/O(space) - –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å
```

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
 * –û—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –≤ —á–∞—Ç —Å –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @param message - –í–∞–ª–∏–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–µ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º–æ–µ)

 * @returns Effect —Å MessageId –∏–ª–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –æ—à–∏–±–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @pure false - —Å–æ–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∏—Ç —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∫–∏
 * @effect DatabaseService, NotificationService
 * @invariant ‚àÄm ‚àà Messages: sent(m) ‚Üí ‚àÉid: persisted(m, id)
 * @precondition message.content.length > 0 ‚àß recipients.length > 0
 * @postcondition ‚àÄr ‚àà recipients: notified(r, message) ‚à® error_logged(r)
 * @complexity O(n) where n = |recipients|
 * @throws Never - –≤—Å–µ –æ—à–∏–±–∫–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ Effect
 */
```

4. **–ò–°–ß–ï–†–ü–´–í–ê–Æ–©–ò–ô –ü–ê–¢–¢–ï–†–ù-–ú–ê–¢–ß–ò–ù–ì**:

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- ton-docs-search: Search official TON documentation via a CLI and return answers with sources and guidance. Use when users ask any question about TON/The Open Network, smart contracts, TVM, wallets, addresses, fees, messages, protocols, tooling, or best practices based on docs.ton.org. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/docs-ton-skill/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

**Refactoring client creation**

I need to refactor the `createClient` function to keep it under 50 lines. One option is to implement a helper function called `createAutoDispatchClient`, which would handle most of the logic. However, if the helper function gets too long, the linter might flag it too.

I should ensure that none of the functions exceed 50 lines. I could also use loops or mapping to minimize repetition. It's important to keep things tidy and efficient!

**Considering dispatcher indexing**

I‚Äôm thinking about using dynamic indexing for dispatchers, which might be tricky from a typing perspective. Although casting can simplify things, I want to avoid `switch` statements as instructed, while loops are fine. 

I could create a constant for HTTP methods and then build an object. However, I can't use `any` or `unknown` due to strict linting rules. Instead, I might explore type assertions, but those are also restricted unless in the axioms module. I‚Äôll have to find a workaround!

**Casting dispatchers correctly**

I‚Äôm realizing that I'll still need to cast dispatchers to method-specific types. Currently, the code safely assigns `resolvedDispatchers` to a specific type like `DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "get">`. 

I can use `asStrictApiClient` from the axioms to cast my object to the `StrictApiClient` type, which is allowed. To manage dynamic method indexing effectively without `any` or `as`, I think creating a helper function called `createMethodHandlerWithDispatchers` is a clever strategy. It‚Äôll improve typing and avoid compilation issues while accessing the dispatchers properly!

**Typing dispatchers correctly**

I need to ensure that `dispatchers[path][method]` is typed correctly. To streamline the `createClient` function, I can use `createAutoDispatchHandler` to set up each method wrapper with the properly typed dispatchers. This will help cut down on repetition by avoiding multiple calls to `createMethodHandler`, making the code cleaner.

However, I still need to keep each method wrapper concise enough to stay below 50 lines overall. I might face challenges with TypeScript's type inference when assigning `resolvedDispatchers`, so I'll need to check if it can be used as needed.

**Designing the file structure**

I‚Äôm considering how to manage the typings for dispatchers correctly, as it appears they're structured as intersections, which limits assignability. To create method wrappers without exceeding 50 lines in `createClient`, I could potentially use an object literal. 

To further streamline the code, I plan to extract large type definitions into a separate file to keep everything below 300 lines. This will involve rearranging types like `ClientOptions`, while ensuring that any core types remain accessible and that I avoid circular imports. 

By re-exporting types from a dedicated types file, I can maintain clarity in my structure. I'll stay cautious about the max lines rule throughout this process!

**Addressing max-lines and types**

I need to tackle the max-lines-per-function issue for `createClient` by keeping its lines below 50. Here‚Äôs the plan:

First, I‚Äôll create a new file for the exported type definitions in `packages/app/src/shell/api-client/create-client-types.ts`. Then, I‚Äôll update `create-client.ts` to import these definitions instead of defining them there.

While refactoring `createClient` to have a single signature, I have to ensure it still returns `StrictApiClientWithDispatchers`. This change means there may no longer be a way to create a manual dispatcher version, but I might still have options. I'll need to explore the `strict-client.ts` file to clarify how `createStrictClient` fits in!

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

–¶–ï–õ–¨: –°–æ–∑–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏ –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—É—é –ø–∞—Ä–∞–¥–∏–≥–º—É —Å –ø–æ–ª–Ω—ã–º —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã—Ö –≤—ã—á–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–∏–π –∏ –∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–ª–∏—Ä—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤.

–ú–û–î–ï–õ–¨ –†–ê–°–°–£–ñ–î–ï–ù–ò–Ø:

  (–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä Effect/FP, —Ä–µ–≤—å—é–µ—Ä —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤, —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∂ CORE‚ÜîSHELL, —Ç–µ—Å—Ç-–∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä).

  –ø–æ –∫—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—è–º –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–æ–≤, —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤–æ–π –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∏ —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ä—É–µ–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏ (–µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å —è–≤–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ—Å–∏—Ç –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä ‚Äî –≤—ã–±—Ä–∞—Ç—å –∏ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å).

–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–û –ü–†–û–¶–ï–°–°–ê (–ù–ï –§–û–†–ú–ê–¢ –û–¢–í–ï–¢–ê):

–õ—é–±–æ–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–∞—Ö, –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —Å–≤–æ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∞—Ö –∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–µ–º—ã—Ö –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞—Ö. –ö–æ–¥ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏—è –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—ã –∏ –ø–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–µ–Ω–∏—è –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–π –º–æ–¥–µ–ª–∏.

–ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ù–´–ï –ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü–´:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- ton-docs-search: Search official TON documentation via a CLI and return answers with sources and guidance. Use when users ask any question about TON/The Open Network, smart contracts, TVM, wallets, addresses, fees, messages, protocols, tooling, or best practices based on docs.ton.org. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/docs-ton-skill/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Optimizing Type Imports**

I‚Äôm considering the necessity of `ParamValue` and `QueryValue` types, which seem less critical since dispatchers types may not be needed for `buildUrl`. Instead, I can focus on `StrictApiClient`, which involves `RequestOptionsFor` that comprises `BodyInit`, `HeadersInit`, and other types.

I‚Äôll make sure to import the relevant types in `create-client.ts`. However, `DispatchersForMethod` is currently internal. If I refactor to a helper function, we might avoid needing it, keeping things cleaner.

**Clarifying TypeScript Indexing**

I‚Äôm trying to figure out if TypeScript will allow indexing for `resolvedDispatchers` based on whether it guarantees the `get` property for each path. `DispatchersFor` is an intersection of `DispatchersForMethod`, creating a type for each path with method-specific objects. If I index using `path`, which combines `PathsForMethod<Paths, "get"> & string`, I wonder if I can access `resolvedDispatchers[path].get`.

However, I might need to assist TypeScript by separating it out or using a variable annotation instead of an `as` cast, which isn‚Äôt allowed.

**Deciding on Type Exports**

I'm looking at how to handle `DispatchersForMethod` when creating `getDispatchers`. This requires it to be accessible in `create-client.ts`, meaning we would need to export it from the types file. It‚Äôs not part of the public API, so while we could export it internally, it might not be preferred. 

Alternatively, we could avoid using `DispatchersForMethod` directly by creating a helper function that needs this type. Ultimately, I think we should go ahead and export `DispatchersForMethod` without making it part of the public API.

**Handling Type Exports Carefully**

I‚Äôm thinking about how to manage the exports from `create-client-types` and `create-client.ts`. If I export from `create-client-types` but don‚Äôt re-export from `create-client.ts`, external users wouldn‚Äôt see it unless they use the internal path. However, to avoid inadvertently including `DispatchersForMethod` through wildcard re-exports, I‚Äôll only export what‚Äôs meant for public use.

So, I‚Äôll ensure that `DispatchersForMethod` is only accessible internally in `create-client.ts`. I‚Äôm also maintaining the existing exports, like `DispatchersFor` and `StrictApiClientWithDispatchers`, while noting that `createClient` returns `StrictApiClientWithDispatchers`.

**Refining Client Implementation**

I‚Äôm planning to keep the `StrictApiClient` type for potential future uses, even if it‚Äôs not currently in use. First, I want to fix the `max-lines-per-function` for `createClient`, which currently has 90 lines. I‚Äôll implement a helper function, `createDispatchingMethodHandler`, which should be concise.

In `createClient`, I‚Äôm aware we need to handle the generic parameters correctly, ensuring `resolvedDispatchers` fits the expected type. While this might lead to some complexity with type inference, it should compile fine.

Moreover, I want to minimize the function's lines while keeping it readable and maintaining the flow of code. I'll ensure compliance with all linting rules for file length and type usage. After making adjustments, I‚Äôll prepare to run tests and commit changes, choosing a relevant message based on the modifications made.

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
 * –û—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –≤ —á–∞—Ç —Å –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∫–æ–π
```

4. **–ò–°–ß–ï–†–ü–´–í–ê–Æ–©–ò–ô –ü–ê–¢–¢–ï–†–ù-–ú–ê–¢–ß–ò–ù–ì**:

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

5. **–≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢–ù–ê–Ø –ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ê**:

```typescript
// CORE: –ß–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
interface MessageRepository {
  readonly save: (msg: Message) => Effect.Effect<MessageId, DatabaseError>

    id: MessageId

// SHELL: –ö–æ–Ω–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è
const PostgresMessageRepository = Layer.effect(
  MessageRepositoryTag,
  Effect.gen(function* (_) {
    const db = yield* _(DatabaseService)
    return {
      save: (msg) => db.insert("messages", msg),
      findById: (id) => db.findOne("messages", { id })
    }
  })
)
```

6. **PROOF-–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–°–¢–í–ê –í PR**:


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Evaluating Generated Modules**

I‚Äôm examining a generated file that imports Paths from test fixtures. It‚Äôs a bit concerning that it imports a type from a test fixture file, which isn‚Äôt typically part of production code. This could complicate build distribution. However, maybe it‚Äôs a template repo using test fixtures for example OpenAPI schemas. It looks like that‚Äôs designed for examples and tests, but having it in the generated directory suggests it might unintentionally include test types.

**Analyzing Test Fixture References**

It seems odd to reference test fixtures within the src directory. This could potentially break the build if the tests folder isn‚Äôt included. I wonder if the tsconfig includes tests? I need to check the build process, which uses `vite build --ssr src/app/main.ts`, but that might not include the generated file at runtime. The `src/generated/index.ts` might be part of the public API, but if referencing test paths breaks builds, we may need to fix it before committing. However, I should confirm the location of `tests/fixtures/petstore.openapi.js`.

**Reviewing Module Imports**

I think the generated module should really be importing Paths from something like `src/generated/schema` instead of the tests. But maybe they haven‚Äôt defined a schema there and are just using test fixtures as a substitute. That seems a little off. I should look up how `petstore.openapi` is being utilized to clarify things further. Checking its usage might help me understand the reasoning behind this setup!

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

```typescript
    pipe(
      sendMessageUseCase(validCommand),
      Effect.provide(MockMessageRepository),
      Effect.provide(MockNotificationService),
      Effect.tap((messageId) =>
        Effect.sync(() => {
          expect(messageId).toEqual(expectedMessageId)
        })
      ),
      Effect.asVoid
    )
  )
})
```

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

**Creating client types file**

It seems like there‚Äôs no existing file, so I can create a new one at `packages/app/src/shell/api-client/create-client-types.ts`. I‚Äôll need to update the `lint:types` script to ensure it checks for any/unknown types since the new file must avoid them. I‚Äôll apply the necessary modifications using `apply_patch`. I think I can copy types from `create-client.ts`, but I should be careful to remove runtime elements. I wonder if I should include top-of-file comments too; I guess minimal comments should work.

**Designing create-client-types.ts**

I'm planning to design the `create-client-types.ts` file. The main goal is to extract the public types from `create-client.ts` into this new module to keep the original file within the linting max-lines while maintaining type-level guarantees. 

I'll start with some comments explaining the purpose, references, and expected effects. Then, I‚Äôll import the necessary types from external libraries and define the `ClientOptions`. I need to decide on exporting `DispatchersForMethod` ‚Äî it might stay internal since I want to use it in `create-client.ts`, but I‚Äôll ensure not to re-export it in the main public index.

**Refining type exports**

I‚Äôm considering whether to export `ParamValue` and `QueryValue`, but maybe they aren‚Äôt necessary. The `StrictApiClient` type uses `Dispatcher`, and it would include similar JSDoc comments. In the types file, I can keep the doc comments, but I might reduce them since it isn't crucial.

In `create-client.ts`, I‚Äôll remove the type definitions and just import the needed types. It looks like after the extraction, `create-client.ts` won‚Äôt need to import some types anymore, just the `Dispatcher` type for the `createMethodHandler` parameter. Also, it‚Äôs important that it still imports `HttpMethod`. I‚Äôll modify `create-client.ts` accordingly.

**Managing import sorting**

I need to handle import sorting carefully, since the linter might enforce `simple-import-sort`. The vibecode-linter runs ESLint and Biome, which can auto-fix issues, but I want to keep things consistent myself. I‚Äôll start by opening the top part of the current `create-client.ts` for precise editing.

Using `apply_patch` might be tricky since the file is large at 646 lines. I‚Äôm considering whether it‚Äôs easier to rewrite sections from scratch or to patch them. Whatever I choose, I need to ensure I don't lose important comments. Rewriting could lead to mistakes, so I‚Äôll be cautious!

**Implementing incremental patch**

I‚Äôm looking to incrementally patch the code. First, I‚Äôll create a `create-client-types.ts` file for the extracted types. Then, I‚Äôll update `create-client.ts` by removing type definitions for `ClientOptions`, `DispatchersForMethod`, and others.

I need to check imports ‚Äî I might eliminate unused imports like `HttpClient` and `Effect`, as they may not be necessary anymore. After extraction, if `Effect` is only for type definitions, it can go. However, I need to keep some types to ensure proper indexing of dispatchers and minimize changes.

I will also maintain types like `ParamValue` and `QueryValue` as they are actively used. For `createDispatchingMethodHandler`, I‚Äôll simplify it using the generic properties. Lastly, I plan to manage exports carefully to keep everything consistent while adhering to the linter‚Äôs guidelines.

**Managing imports and exports**

I‚Äôm figuring out how to handle imports and exports efficiently. I can import types like `ClientOptions`, `DispatchersFor`, `DispatchersForMethod`, and `StrictApiClientWithDispatchers` from `create-client-types.js`, then re-export them to keep everything organized. 

It seems okay to have them both imported and exported even if it feels a bit redundant. The plan is to ensure that all necessary types are available without duplicates in `create-client.ts`. I‚Äôll implement the patch accordingly, starting with the addition of the new file.

*** Add File: packages/app/src/shell/api-client/create-client-types.ts
+// CHANGE: Extract public createClient types into dedicated module
+// WHY: Keep create-client.ts under lint max-lines without weakening type-level invariants
+// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "–¢–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø—Ä–æ–≥–æ–Ω–∏ –ø–æ –≤—Å–µ–º—É –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç—É –ª–∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—ã"
+// REF: user-msg-2
+// SOURCE: n/a
+// PURITY: CORE
+// EFFECT: none
+// INVARIANT: All type-level correlations remain unchanged
+// COMPLEXITY: O(1) compile-time / O(0) runtime
+
+import type * as HttpClient from "@effect/platform/HttpClient"
+import type { Effect } from "effect"
+import type { HttpMethod } from "openapi-typescript-helpers"
+
+import type {
+  ApiFailure,
+  ApiSuccess,
+  OperationFor,
+  PathsForMethod,
+  RequestOptionsFor,
+  ResponsesFor
+} from "../../core/api-client/strict-types.js"
+import type { Dispatcher } from "../../core/axioms.js"
+
+/**
+ * Client configuration options
+ *
+ * @pure - immutable configuration
+ */
+export type ClientOptions = {
+  readonly baseUrl: string
+  readonly credentials?: RequestCredentials
+  readonly headers?: HeadersInit
+  readonly fetch?: typeof globalThis.fetch
+}
+
+// CHANGE: Add dispatcher map type for auto-dispatching clients
+// WHY: Enable creating clients that infer dispatcher from path+method without per-call parameter
+// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "ApiClient –∏ —Ç–∞–∫ –∑–Ω–∞–µ—Ç —Ç–µ–∫—É—â–∏–µ —Ç–∏–ø—ã. –ó–∞—á–µ–º –ø–µ—Ä–µ–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å —á—Ç–æ –ª–∏–±–æ –≤ GET"
+// REF: user-msg-1
+// SOURCE: n/a
+// FORMAT THEOREM: ‚àÄ path, method: dispatchers[path][method] = Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, path, method>>>
+// PURITY: CORE
+// EFFECT: none
+// INVARIANT: dispatcher map is total for all operations in Paths
+// COMPLEXITY: O(1) compile-time / O(0) runtime
+export type DispatchersForMethod<
+  Paths extends object,
+  Method extends HttpMethod
+> = {
+  readonly [Path in PathsForMethod<Paths, Method>]: {
+    readonly [K in Method]: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, Method>>>
+  }
+}
+
+export type DispatchersFor<Paths extends object> =
+  & DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "get">
+  & DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "post">
+  & DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "put">
+  & DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "delete">
+  & DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "patch">
+  & DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "head">
+  & DispatchersForMethod<Paths, "options">
+
+/**
+ * Type-safe API client with full request-side type enforcement
+ *
+ * **Key guarantees:**
+ * 1. GET only works on paths that have `get` method in schema
+ * 2. POST only works on paths that have `post` method in schema
+ * 3. Dispatcher type is derived from operation's responses
+ * 4. Request options (params/query/body) are derived from operation
+ *
+ * **Effect Channel Design:**
+ * - Success channel: `ApiSuccess<Responses>` - 2xx responses only
+ * - Error channel: `ApiFailure<Responses>` - HTTP errors (4xx, 5xx) + boundary errors
+ *
+ * @typeParam Paths - OpenAPI paths type from openapi-typescript
+ *
+ * @pure false - operations perform HTTP requests
+ * @invariant ‚àÄ call: path ‚àà PathsForMethod<Paths, method> ‚àß options derived from operation
+ */
+export type StrictApiClient<Paths extends object> = {
+  /**
+   * Execute GET request
+   *
+   * @typeParam Path - Path that supports GET method (enforced at type level)
+   * @param path - API path with GET method
+   * @param dispatcher - Response dispatcher (must match operation responses)
+   * @param options - Request options (typed from operation)
+   * @returns Effect with 2xx in success channel, errors in error channel
+   */
+  readonly GET: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "get">>(
+    path: Path,
+    dispatcher: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "get">>>,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "get">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "get">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "get">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute POST request
+   */
+  readonly POST: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "post">>(
+    path: Path,
+    dispatcher: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "post">>>,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "post">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "post">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "post">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute PUT request
+   */
+  readonly PUT: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "put">>(
+    path: Path,
+    dispatcher: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "put">>>,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "put">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "put">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "put">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute DELETE request
+   */
+  readonly DELETE: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "delete">>(
+    path: Path,
+    dispatcher: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "delete">>>,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "delete">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "delete">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "delete">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute PATCH request
+   */
+  readonly PATCH: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "patch">>(
+    path: Path,
+    dispatcher: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "patch">>>,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "patch">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "patch">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "patch">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute HEAD request
+   */
+  readonly HEAD: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "head">>(
+    path: Path,
+    dispatcher: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "head">>>,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "head">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "head">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "head">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute OPTIONS request
+   */
+  readonly OPTIONS: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "options">>(
+    path: Path,
+    dispatcher: Dispatcher<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "options">>>,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "options">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "options">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "options">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+}
+
+/**
+ * Type-safe API client with auto-dispatching (dispatcher is derived from path+method)
+ *
+ * **Key guarantees:**
+ * 1. GET only works on paths that have `get` method in schema
+ * 2. Dispatcher is looked up from provided dispatcher map by path+method
+ * 3. Request options (params/query/body) are derived from operation
+ *
+ * **Effect Channel Design:**
+ * - Success channel: `ApiSuccess<Responses>` - 2xx responses only
+ * - Error channel: `ApiFailure<Responses>` - HTTP errors (4xx, 5xx) + boundary errors
+ *
+ * @typeParam Paths - OpenAPI paths type from openapi-typescript
+ *
+ * @pure false - operations perform HTTP requests
+ * @invariant ‚àÄ call: path ‚àà PathsForMethod<Paths, method> ‚àß dispatcherMap[path][method] defined
+ */
+export type StrictApiClientWithDispatchers<Paths extends object> = {
+  /**
+   * Execute GET request (dispatcher is inferred)
+   */
+  readonly GET: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "get">>(
+    path: Path,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "get">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "get">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "get">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute POST request (dispatcher is inferred)
+   */
+  readonly POST: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "post">>(
+    path: Path,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "post">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "post">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "post">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute PUT request (dispatcher is inferred)
+   */
+  readonly PUT: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "put">>(
+    path: Path,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "put">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "put">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "put">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute DELETE request (dispatcher is inferred)
+   */
+  readonly DELETE: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "delete">>(
+    path: Path,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "delete">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "delete">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "delete">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute PATCH request (dispatcher is inferred)
+   */
+  readonly PATCH: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "patch">>(
+    path: Path,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "patch">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "patch">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "patch">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute HEAD request (dispatcher is inferred)
+   */
+  readonly HEAD: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "head">>(
+    path: Path,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "head">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "head">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "head">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+
+  /**
+   * Execute OPTIONS request (dispatcher is inferred)
+   */
+  readonly OPTIONS: <Path extends PathsForMethod<Paths, "options">>(
+    path: Path,
+    options?: RequestOptionsFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "options">>
+  ) => Effect.Effect<
+    ApiSuccess<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "options">>>,
+    ApiFailure<ResponsesFor<OperationFor<Paths, Path, "options">>>,
+    HttpClient.HttpClient
+  >
+}
+
*** End Patch

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/openapi-effect/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- ton-docs-search: Search official TON documentation via a CLI and return answers with sources and guidance. Use when users ask any question about TON/The Open Network, smart contracts, TVM, wallets, addresses, fees, messages, protocols, tooling, or best practices based on docs.ton.org. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/docs-ton-skill/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.
